results.headline: Watch Out, He’s Packing a Blow-Dryer
results.display_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of You Don't Mess With the Zohan

results.summary_short: Let me be blunt: “You Don’t Mess With the Zohan” is the finest post-Zionist action-hairdressing sex comedy I have ever seen.

results.headline: Scratching and Clawing Their Way to the Middle

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Promotion

results.summary_short: “The Promotion” tells you everything you might want to know but were too uninterested to ask about working as an assistant manager in a supermarket.

results.headline: Sex, Cinema, Marriage and Other Dangerous Activities

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Wedding Director

results.summary_short: In “The Wedding Director,” Sergio Castellitto, the film’s star, is the perfect vessel for the director Marco Bellocchio’s playful, sorrowful sensibility.

results.headline: Good Deed, Unscripted Consequences

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Operation Filmmaker

results.summary_short: “Operation Filmmaker” is an absorbing story about the best intentions gone terribly and comically awry.

results.headline: Impish Writer on the Edge of Tomorrow

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dreams With Sharp Teeth

results.summary_short: Directed by Erik Nelson, “Dreams With Sharp Teeth” recalls the career of Harlan Ellison, a runty young geek who evolved into a world-famous artist.

results.headline: Mixing Art and Science to Get Doomsday
results.display_title: Wonders Are Many: The Making of Doctor Atomic

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wonders Are Many: The Making of Doctor Atomic

results.summary_short: The enthralling documentary “Wonders Are Many: The Making of Doctor Atomic” follows the creation of a lofty operatic collaboration.

results.headline: Tales of a Goofball Guru

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Foot Fist Way

results.summary_short: “The Foot Fist Way” is an itsy-bitsy, ultra-indie, super-silly comedy packing huge laughs and unexpected heart.

results.headline: A Slow Crescendo of Intimidation

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Strangers

results.summary_short: “The Strangers” proves adept at eliciting the fear and dislocation that accompany the violation of our most sacred space.

results.headline: Steroid Myth, Scandals and Dreams

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bigger, Stronger, Faster*

results.summary_short: Just when “Bigger, Stronger, Faster*” seems content to be an entertaining exploration of the use of anabolic steroids, it turns a corner and plunges into deeper waters.

results.headline: Through a Peephole: Woman on a Quest

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Unknown Woman

results.summary_short: Giuseppe Tornatore’s sleazy Hitchcockian thriller, “The Unknown Woman,” keeps you glued to the screen despite your increasingly nagging doubts about its integrity.

results.headline: Sorry, Your Body’s in My Windshield

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stuck

results.summary_short: There are no supernatural happenings, just people under extreme stress succumbing to their worst instincts, in Stuart Gordon’s grim, expert little thriller “Stuck.”

results.headline: Lustrous, Glittering, Monied Dysfunction

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Savage Grace

results.summary_short: “Savage Grace,” Tom Kalin’s long-awaited second feature (after “Swoon”), swoons through a number of lovely, storied places on its way to a sad and sordid end.

results.headline: The Girls Are Back in Town

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sex and the City

results.summary_short: A little Botox goes a long way in “Sex and the City,” but a little decent writing would have gone even further.

results.headline: A Tomboy in Malaysia Is Introduced to Hormones

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mukhsin

results.summary_short: Deceptively simple and threaded with gentle humor, “Mukhsin” paints the turmoil of puppy love on a canvas of family relationships as delightful as it is believable.

results.headline: Anarchy With a Short Attention Span

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Postal

results.summary_short: Infantile, irreverent and boorish to the max, “Postal” explodes with bad attitude and lousy filmmaking.

results.headline: How to Rock in Iraq

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Heavy Metal in Baghdad

results.summary_short: Iraq documentary fatigue gets a rock-hard slap in the face with “Heavy Metal in Baghdad,” an intrepid, unlikely and altogether splendid feat of D.I.Y. reportage.

results.headline: Retrofitted for Revenge

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Machine Girl

results.summary_short: The Japanese obsession with cavorting ninjas and cunning hardware reaches some kind of climax with “The Machine Girl.”

results.headline: A Hit Man in a War Zone That Could Easily Be Iraq

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of War, Inc.

results.summary_short: The zany, nihilistic “War, Inc.” is gonzo moviemaking with a bleeding heart.

results.headline: Invasion of the Heart

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Children of Huang Shi

results.summary_short: “The Children of Huang Shi” is a Hollywood weepie snuggled inside a humanitarian tribute.

results.headline: The Further Adventures of the Fedora and Whip
results.display_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull

results.summary_short: There’s plenty of frantic energy in “Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull,” lots of noise and money too, but what’s absent is any sense of rediscovery.
